   63M with HTN, ITP, admitted with neurologic changes and found to have
   lyme encephalitis.
   .
   # Lyme encephalitis.  Highly suspected based on MR findings, serum and
   CSF serologies.  On stable treatment course for planned 4 weeks with
   ceftriaxone.  With some persistent neurologic deficits.
   - 28 day course of ceftriaxone - clarify date of last dose.
   - Neurology following; unclear if deficits permanent.
   .
   # Agitation/altered mental status.  Multifactorial delerium -
   electrolyte abnormalities, encephalitis, med related.  Also with some
   chronic narcotic use.
   - Correct lytes
   - Methadone 10 mg TID given chronic pain control issues.
   - Seroquel 25 mg [**Hospital1 **] for agitation.
   - Can also give Haldol prn agitation.
   .
   # Respiratory failure.  Difficulty weaning off vent now s/p trach.
   Seems to desat with plugging/secretions at times.  Atelectasis on
   imaging.  [**Month (only) 11**] be hypoventilating to some degree with sedation meds as
   above. Recent mini-BAL negative. Today tolerating trach mask well.
   - CXR today.
   - Continue vent wean as tolerated.
   - Continue inhaled meds as prior for bronchospasm (no clear history of
   COPD, though with significant smoking history).
   .
   # Fever.  Daily low grade temps [**Date range (1) 9233**] (100-100.3); Tmax 102.8
   yesterday.  Blood cultures drawn; urine with a few WBCs.  CXR without
   evidence of infiltrate though was one day prior.
   - Repeat CXR.
   - Sputum culture.
   - Repeat UA with culture.
   - Send C.diff.
   - d/c PICC and send tip culture.
   .
   # Hypernatremia.  Likely iatrogenic.
   - Free water in tube feeds doubled today.
   - 1 more liter of D5W today.
   - repeat lytes in PM today.
   .
   # Corneal ulcer.  s/p eyelid suturing with ophthal.  Likely related to
   inability to protect eye with neurologic deficits.
   - vigamox and bacitracin ointment.
   - clarify treatment duration with ophthalmology.
   .
   # Elevated LFTs.  Mild yesterday. ?ceftriaxone related.
   - Recheck tomorrow.
   - If still abnormal, check RUQ US.
   .
   # Accelerated idioventricular rhythm.  Cards saw; though benign and not
   related to lyme disease.
   - Continue metoprolol at current dosing.
   .
   # HTN.  Well controlled on metoprolol; written for prn
   antihypertensives, which we will hold.
   - continue metoprolol.
   .

Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of hypertension, ITP, admitted with neurologic changes and found to have lyme encephalitis. The patient is currently on a stable treatment course for planned 4 weeks with ceftriaxone. Some persistent neurologic deficits are noted. 

The patient also has agitation/altered mental status, likely multifactorial delirium - electrolyte abnormalities, encephalitis, med-related. Methadone 10 mg TID is given for chronic pain control issues. Seroquel 25 mg is given for agitation. Haldol prn is also an option. 

The patient has respiratory failure, difficulty weaning off vent now s/p trach. He seems to desat with plugging/secretions at times. Atelectasis on imaging is present. Recent mini-BAL negative. The patient tolerates trach mask well. 

Fever is present with daily low-grade temps ranging from 100-100.3; Tmax 102.8 yesterday. Blood cultures have been drawn; urine shows a few WBCs. CXR without evidence of infiltrate though was one day prior. 

Hypernatremia is likely iatrogenic. Free water in tube feeds has been doubled today. Another liter of D5W today. Repeat lytes in PM today. 

A corneal ulcer is present s/p eyelid suturing with ophthalmology. It is likely

 [**Last Name **] PROBLEM - ENTER DESCRIPTION IN COMMENTS Bells Palsy
   63M with HTN, ITP, admitted with neurologic changes and found to have
   lyme encephalitis.  Now transferred with continued altered mental
   status and fever.
   .
   # Hypotension: had period of hypotension overnight with SBPs to 70s.
   Responded to IV fluids and started on vanc, zosyn and cipro for a
   presumed hospital acquired pneumonia (had had CXR that should possible
   new RLL infiltrates).  The hypotension also happened soon after
   receiving several medications, and was repeated this morning after
   receiving metoprolol, clonidine, methadone and seroquel.
   - Final read for CXR infiltrates is equivocal and patient was
   afebrile.  It is unclear whether he has a new infection.  Also,
   considering that he was already on ceftriaxone, not sure if adding
   zosyn is useful.  We can continue antibiotics for 48 hours after all
   cultures negative.
   - He had had a cards consult for tachycardia, which they felt was an
   accelerated idioventricular rhythm that would not likely respond to
   metoprolol, but his metoprolol was still increased to 75mg TID.  We
   will reduce his dose to 25mg TID to avoid hypotension.
   .
   # Lyme encephalitis.  Highly suspected based on MR findings, serum and
   CSF serologies.  On stable treatment course for planned 4 weeks with
   ceftriaxone.  With some persistent neurologic deficits.
   - Though second CSF serology is equivocal, they definitely feel that
   his picture is
   - 28 day course of ceftriaxone
 now day 22 of 28.
   - Neurology following; unclear if deficits permanent.
   .
   # Agitation/altered mental status. Primarily due to encephalitis,
   though could be multifactorial - electrolyte abnormalities, other
   concurrent infection, med related.  Also with some chronic narcotic
   use.  He responds well to PRN haldol, but we will try to avoid chemical
   sedation and restraints with frequent re-orientation.
   - Methadone 10 mg TID given chronic pain control issues.
   - Seroquel 25 mg [**Hospital1 **] for agitation.
   - Can also give Haldol 2mg prn agitation.
   - Given that nutritional deficits appear very unlikely, we will d/c IV
   thiamine, folate and multivitamin.
   .
   # Respiratory failure.  Now doing well at 20 hours on trach mask. Seems
   to desat with plugging/secretions at times.  Atelectasis on imaging.
   - f/u CXR read.
   - Continue vent wean as tolerated.
   - Continue inhaled meds as prior for bronchospasm (no clear history of
   COPD, though with significant smoking history).
   .
   # Fever.  Daily low grade temps [**Date range (1) 9233**] (100-100.3); Tmax 102.8
   yesterday.  Blood cultures drawn; urine with a few WBCs.  CXR without
   evidence of infiltrate though was one day prior.
   - Repeat CXR.
   - Sputum culture.
   - Repeat UA with culture.
   - Send C.diff.
   - d/c PICC and send tip culture.
   .
   # Hypernatremia.  Improved yesterday.  Will continue to monitor with
   free water boluses w/ tube feeds.
   - Free water in tube feeds doubled yesterday.
   - repeat lytes in PM.
   .
   # Corneal ulcer.  s/p eyelid suturing with ophthal.  Likely related to
   inability to protect eye with neurologic deficits.
   - vigamox and bacitracin ointment.
   - f/u ophthalmology recs..
   .
   # Elevated LFTs.  Mild yesterday, slightly worsened today.  Unclear
   etiology, possibly due to ceftriaxone.
   - Continue to trend.  If he has fevers again, would get ultrasound.
   .
   # Accelerated idioventricular rhythm.  Cards saw; thought benign and
   not related to lyme disease.
   - Continue metoprolol at current dosing.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of hypertension and ITP admitted with neurologic changes and diagnosed with Lyme encephalitis. He has altered mental status, fever, and a previous diagnosis of Bells Palsy. The patient has been transferred from another facility with continued altered mental status and fever.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypotension: The patient experienced episodes of hypotension overnight and in the morning, which responded to IV fluids and empiric antibiotics for presumed hospital-acquired pneumonia. The hypotension also occurred after receiving several medications.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient initially required respiratory support but is now doing well at 20 hours on a tracheal mask. There is a concern for atelectasis and the need to continue weaning off the ventilator as tolerated.

3. Fever: The patient has had daily low-grade temperatures, with a Tmax of 102.8 yesterday. Blood cultures have been drawn, and further investigations are needed to identify the cause of the fever.

4. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels improved yesterday but require close monitoring with free water boluses during tube feeds.

5. Corneal Ulcer: The patient has a corneal ulcer that may be related to his neurologic deficits. Ophthalmology follow-up recommendations have been given.

6. Elevated Liver Function Tests (LFTs): The patient's LFTs have shown mild elevation and wors

 now day 24 of 28.

   concurrent infection, med related.  Also with some chronic narcotic

Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of hypertension, ITP, and admitted with neurologic changes. He was found to have Lyme encephalitis and transferred with continued altered mental status and fever. The patient's medical conditions include hypotension, Lyme encephalitis, agitation/altered mental status, respiratory failure, fever, hypernatremia, corneal ulcer, and elevated liver function tests.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is currently doing well on a tracheostomy mask and seems to desaturate with plugging/secretions at times. Atelectasis on imaging has been noted. Continuous monitoring and weaning of the ventilator as tolerated is advised.

2. Agitation/altered mental status: The patient's agitation can be due to encephalitis, but could also be multifactorial - electrolyte abnormalities, other concurrent infection, or medication-related. Frequent re-orientation and PRN haldol have been helpful in managing agitation.

3. Fever: The patient has had daily low-grade temperatures with a maximum temperature of 102.8 yesterday. Blood cultures have been drawn, and further investigations are pending to determine the cause of the fever.

4. Hypernatremia: The patient's serum sodium levels are elevated, and efforts have been made to improve it with free water boluses. Close monitoring and continued management are necessary.

5. Corneal ulcer

Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of hypertension, ITP, admitted with neurologic changes and found to have Lyme encephalitis. He is currently in the ICU with multiple medical complications. The patient's medical history includes bells palsy, hypotension, Lyme encephalitis, tachycardia, agitation/altered mental status, respiratory failure, fever, corneal ulcer, elevated liver function tests, accelerated idioventricular rhythm, and hypernatremia.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.4°C (99.4°F), heart rate of 91 bpm, blood pressure of 139/58 mmHg, respiratory rate of 10 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient is on mechanical ventilation via tracheostomy tube with CPAP/PSV mode, set Vt of 450 mL, PS of 5 cmH2O, RR set at 20, PEEP of 8 cmH2O, FiO2 of 50%, and RSBI of 27.

The patient's physical examination reveals that he is awake, alert, and tries to answer questions but cannot talk due to tracheostomy, follows commands, and has tremor in his left hand. Coarse rhonchi are heard bilaterally, and his cardiovascular and abdominal examinations are benign without any signs of lower extremity edema.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of Lyme encephalitis, respiratory failure, and delirium. He was previously on mechanical ventilation but was extubated yesterday due to improved respiratory status. However, he experienced an episode of mucous plugging and required reintubation. The patient's current condition is stable, with improved mental status and respiratory function. He is still experiencing encephalopathy and delirium. The patient has been diagnosed with respiratory failure, acute on chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and Lyme disease. He also has altered mental status, which is not consistent with delirium.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory function can deteriorate further, leading to increased difficulty in breathing and potential need for prolonged mechanical ventilation.
2. Delirium: The patient's mental status remains altered, and there is a risk of worsening delirium, which can impact his overall prognosis and recovery.
3. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing new infections due to his immunocompromised state and prolonged hospital stay. Close monitoring for signs of infection is essential.
4. Thromboembolic Events: Immobility and critical illness increase the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE). Prophylactic measures such as low molecular weight heparin should be continued.
5. Neurological Complications: Lyme en

The patient is a 63-year-old male with a chief complaint of Lyme encephalitis and respiratory failure. He is currently in the ICU and has been intubated due to episodes of mucous plugging. The patient's history includes confusion, delirium, anemia, and Bell's Palsy. He has been treated with various antibiotics for Lyme disease, including piperacillin/tazobactam, ciprofloxacin, ceftriaxone, and cefepime. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4°C (99.4°F), heart rate of 72 bpm, blood pressure of 94/67 mmHg, respiratory rate of 11 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. His ABG results show a pH of 7.35, PaCO2 of 35 mmHg, and PaO2 of 103 mmHg.    63M with HTN, ITP, admitted with neurologic changes and found to have

   status and fever.
   # Hypotension: Has been having periods of hypotension with SBPs to
   80s.  Responded to IV fluids and started on vanc, cefepime and cipro
   for a presumed hospital acquired pneumonia (had had CXR that showed
   possible new RLL infiltrates).  The hypotension also happened soon
   after receiving several medications, and was repeated yesterday morning
   after receiving metoprolol, clonidine, methadone and seroquel. Unclear
   that this hypotension represents a brewing sepsis. Afebrile since
   [**2102-10-16**] at 4pm. Will try stopping some antihypertensives and see if
   this improves. D/c clonodine given that he is on metoprolol for control
   of HR after an accelerated idioventricular rhythm
   - Taper clonodine
   -Clonodine taper: 0.1 mg [**Hospital1 **] x3 days, then 0.1 mg daily x3 days, then
   off
   - He had had a cards consult for tachycardia, which they felt was an
   accelerated idioventricular rhythm that would not likely respond to
   metoprolol, but his metoprolol was still increased to 75mg TID, but
   then backed down to 25mg TID.
   # Lyme encephalitis.  Highly suspected based on MR findings, serum and
   CSF serologies.  On stable treatment course for planned 4 weeks with
   ceftriaxone.  With some persistent neurologic deficits.
   - Have spoke to pharmacy
 Cefipime not good Lyme coverage and

   - 28 day course of ceftriaxone
 now day 25 of 28.

   # Agitation/altered mental status. Primarily due to encephalitis,
   though could be multifactorial - electrolyte abnormalities, other
   concurrent infection, med related.  Also with some chronic narcotic
   use.  He responds well to PRN haldol, but we will try to avoid chemical
   sedation and restraints with frequent re-orientation. Will try to
   minimize all medications. Also increase seroquel given that he has had
   periods where he appears more normal and then periods where he appears
   more confused (waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 282**]).
   - Pt has been on Methadone 10 mg TID for chronic pain control issues
   but will try to wean this off as not clear that pt is in pain and that
   he needs it. Will contact pharmacy about how to wean safely.
   - Seroquel 25 mg TID for agitation.
   # Respiratory failure.  Patient on trache mask yesterday, had an
   episode of desaturation so placed back on vent.  Per notes seems to
   have been related to secretions. CXR today does appear improved, making
   PNA less likely. Sputum cultures have been negative.
   - Continue vent wean as tolerated
   - Continue inhaled meds as prior for bronchospasm (no clear history of

s were added on due to transient hypotense episodes. All

s. PT was
   started on cefepime, vanco and cipro, but in the setting of negative
   cultures will plan to d/c these antibiotics. Also trying to minimize
   medications in the setting of confusion and agitation. No clear

   # Corneal ulcer.  s/p eyelid suturing with ophthal.  Likely related to

   - f/u ophthalmology recs..

   - Continue to trend.  If he has fevers again, would further address
   # Accelerated idioventricular rhythm.  Cards saw; thought benign and
   not related to lyme disease.

Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of hypertension, ITP, admitted with neurologic changes and found to have Lyme encephalitis. He is currently in the ICU with multiple medical complications. 

1. The patient has been on a planned 4-week course of ceftriaxone for Lyme encephalitis, now on day 25. However, it was noted that ceftriaxone is not good coverage for Pseudomonas, so there is a concern about potential antibiotic resistance.
2. The patient has been experiencing periods of hypotension, which responded to IV fluids and started on vancomycin, cefepime, and cipro for presumed hospital-acquired pneumonia. However, recent cultures have been negative, making PNA less likely.
3. The patient had an episode of desaturation while on tracheal mask, leading to the decision to place him back on mechanical ventilation. His respiratory status is improving, and weaning from the ventilator is being attempted as tolerated.
4. The patient has chronic narcotic use and is currently on methadone for pain control. An attempt will be made to wean off methadone safely.
5. The patient has been experiencing agitation and altered mental status, primarily due to encephalitis. He responds well to PRN haldol but will try to minimize chemical sedation and restraints.
6. The patient has elevated liver function tests, which

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of hypertension and ITP, admitted for neurologic changes and diagnosed with Lyme encephalitis. He is currently being treated with ceftriaxone for Lyme disease and has shown some persistent neurologic deficits. The patient has also been experiencing agitation and altered mental status, which is believed to be primarily due to encephalitis but may also be caused by electrolyte abnormalities, concurrent infection, or medication-related factors. 

The patient has had episodes of hypotension, which responded to IV fluids and the initiation of vancomycin, zosyn, and cipro for a presumed hospital-acquired pneumonia. However, his blood pressure is currently stable. 

He has a history of tachycardia, for which he was evaluated by cardiology and found to have an accelerated idioventricular rhythm. Metoprolol was increased but then reduced to 25mg TID. 

The patient has respiratory failure and is currently doing well on a tracheostomy mask. He has atelectasis on imaging but is expected to undergo a tracheostomy mask trial today. 

The patient has had a fever but has been afebrile since October 16th. Cultures have been negative, and broad-spectrum antibiotics have been started due to transient hypotensive episodes. 

He also has a corneal ulcer that occurred after eyelid suturing and is believed

The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of hypertension, ITP, admitted for neurologic changes and diagnosed with Lyme encephalitis. He has been experiencing altered mental status, agitation, and fever. The patient also has respiratory failure, corneal ulcer, elevated liver function tests, and an accelerated idioventricular rhythm.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is currently being managed with mechanical ventilation due to episodes of desaturation related to secretions. There is a concern for hospital-acquired pneumonia, but recent sputum cultures have been negative.

2. Lyme Encephalitis: The patient is on a stable treatment course of ceftriaxone for planned 4 weeks, but there are concerns about persistent neurologic deficits and the potential for permanent damage.

3. Corneal Ulcer: The patient has a corneal ulcer that is likely related to his inability to protect his eye due to neurologic deficits. He is currently receiving topical antibiotics.

4. Accelerated Idioventricular Rhythm: The patient had an episode of accelerated idioventricular rhythm, which was evaluated by cardiology and deemed benign.

5. Electrolyte Abnormalities: The patient has had elevated levels of potassium and slightly low levels of bicarbonate, which need to be closely monitored and corrected if necessary.

Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of hypertension, ITP, admitted with neurologic changes and found to have Lyme encephalitis. He has continued altered mental status, fever, and neurologic deficits. The patient's current medications include ceftriaxone for Lyme disease, seroquel for agitation, and methadone for chronic pain control. The patient's recent laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, elevated liver enzymes, and abnormal electrolyte levels. Imaging studies reveal right pleural effusion, elevated and atelectatic right lung base, and mild atelectasis at the left base. The patient's vital signs are stable, and he is currently on mechanical ventilation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's history of neurologic changes, altered mental status, and periods of apnea while sleeping may indicate a risk for respiratory failure. The presence of elevated and atelectatic right lung base also suggests possible impaired gas exchange.
2. Hypotension: The patient has had periods of hypotension with systolic blood pressures in the 80s. This could be due to sepsis or an adverse reaction to medications.
3. Lyme Disease: The patient has been diagnosed with Lyme encephalitis and is currently on a stable treatment course of ceftriaxone. However, there is a concern for persistent neurologic deficits.
4. Agitation/Altered

Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of hypertension, ITP, admitted with neurologic changes and diagnosed with Lyme encephalitis. He has been on a stable treatment course of ceftriaxone for planned 4 weeks, now on day 26 of 28. The patient's primary issues include agitation/altered mental status, respiratory failure, metabolic alkalosis, hypotension, fever, corneal ulcer, elevated LFTs, and an accelerated idioventricular rhythm.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status has improved, but there are still periods of apnea when sleeping. A tracheostomy trial today is planned to continue weaning off the ventilator.
2. Metabolic Alkalosis: Bicarb levels are trending up, and urine chloride will be checked to assess if the patient is volume depleted. Diamox will be given.
3. Hypotension: The patient has had periods of low blood pressure in the 80s, and IV fluids have been started. Some antihypertensive medications will be stopped to improve blood pressure.
4. Lyme Disease: The patient has been diagnosed with Lyme encephalitis, and he is currently on ceftriaxone for treatment. Neurology follow-up is planned to assess neurologic deficits.
5. Corneal Ulcer: The patient has a corneal ulcer likely related to neuro

Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of hypertension and ITP, admitted with neurological changes and diagnosed with Lyme encephalitis. He has altered mental status, fever, respiratory failure, agitation, hypotension, and a corneal ulcer. The patient is currently on a 28-day course of ceftriaxone for Lyme disease and has been weaned off some medications. His vital signs are relatively stable, but he remains on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. The patient's recent cultures have been negative, and his CXR shows improvement in bilateral base opacification. The plan is to continue weaning him off the ventilator and minimize medications. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. There is a potential risk of further deterioration in respiratory function, which could lead to prolonged ventilation or the need for tracheostomy.
2. Agitation/Altered Mental Status: The patient's agitation and altered mental status may persist or worsen, potentially leading to increased confusion, delirium, or aggression.
3. Hypotension: The patient has had episodes of hypotension, which can increase the risk of shock or organ dysfunction if not properly managed.
4. Corneal Ulcer: The patient has a corneal ulcer that requires regular monitoring and treatment to prevent complications such as vision loss or infection.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of hypertension, ITP, admitted with neurological changes and diagnosed with Lyme encephalitis. He is currently on a stable treatment course of ceftriaxone for planned 4 weeks. The patient has shown some persistent neurological deficits, and Neurology is following up on this. The patient also has agitation/altered mental status, primarily due to encephalitis, but could be multifactorial. He responds well to PRN haldol and will try to minimize all medications. His respiratory failure has improved, making pneumonia less likely, and sputum cultures have been negative. The patient has periods of apnea when sleeping, and a tracheostomy tube trial today is planned. Metabolic alkalosis is suspected due to bicarb trending up, and urine chloride will be checked. Hypotension has been addressed with IV fluids and stopping some antihypertensives. The patient has a history of smoking and may have COPD. A consultation for tachycardia was done, and metoprolol was given for an accelerated idioventricular rhythm. The patient also has a corneal ulcer s/p eyelid suturing, elevated LFTs possibly due to ceftriaxone, and an accelerated idioventricular rhythm.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Neurological deficits due to Lyme encephalitis.
2. Agitation and altered mental status

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of hypertension and ITP, admitted with neurologic changes and diagnosed with Lyme encephalitis. He has been on a stable treatment course of ceftriaxone for planned 4 weeks, with some persistent neurologic deficits. The patient also has agitation/altered mental status, which could be due to encephalitis or other factors. He is responding well to PRN haldol but will try to avoid chemical sedation and restraints. Methadone for chronic pain control is being weaned off. The patient has had periods of hypotension and is being treated for a presumed hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) with IV fluids and antibiotics. His respiratory failure is improving, and the need for mechanical ventilation is being weaned off. The patient had a corneal ulcer post eyelid suturing and is being treated with vigamox and bacitracin ointment. Elevated liver function tests are improving but still need monitoring. The patient's accelerated idioventricular rhythm is being managed with metoprolol.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is a significant concern. He had an episode of desaturation leading to the reintroduction of mechanical ventilation. Although his CXR has improved, there is still a risk of recurrent respiratory failure due to secretions or underlying lung pathology.

2. Agitation/Altered Mental Status:

Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of hypertension and intracerebral thrombosis, admitted with neurological changes and diagnosed with Lyme encephalitis. He is currently on a stable treatment course of ceftriaxone for 4 weeks. The patient's mental status remains altered, and he has periods of agitation. There is a concern for potential medical complications such as respiratory failure, hypotension, fever, corneal ulcer, elevated liver function tests, and an accelerated idioventricular rhythm. The patient's current medications include ceftriaxone, haldol, seroquel, methadone, and metoprolol. The family meeting was held to discuss goals of care, including weaning from the ventilator, improving mental status, and continuing to search for any sources and signs of infection. Long-term acute rehab was discussed as the most likely next destination.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has impaired respiration/gas exchange and has periods of apnea while sleeping. A tracheostomy trial is planned today.
2. Hypotension: The patient has had episodes of low blood pressure in the 80s. IV fluids and antibiotics were started for presumed hospital-acquired pneumonia, but recent cultures have been negative.
3. Fever: The patient had daily low-grade temperatures until October 16th but has been afebrile since then. Antibiotics were initially

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a middle-aged male with a history of hypertension, ITP, admitted with neurologic changes and found to have Lyme encephalitis. He is currently on a stable treatment course for planned 4 weeks with ceftriaxone. The patient's agitation and altered mental status are primarily due to encephalitis, although other factors like electrolyte abnormalities, concurrent infection, and medication may also contribute. He responds well to PRN haldol but will try to minimize chemical sedation and restraints by frequent re-orientation and medication reduction. The patient's respiratory failure appears to be improving, making pneumonia less likely. Sputum cultures have been negative. The patient will continue with vent wean as tolerated and inhaled meds for bronchospasm.

The patient has periods of apnea when sleeping, and a tracheostomy tube trial is planned today. Metabolic alkalosis is present with bicarb trending up, so urine chloride will be checked to assess for possible volume depletion. The patient's hypotension responded to IV fluids and started on vancomycin, cefepime, and cipro for presumed hospital-acquired pneumonia. Some antihypertensives will be tapered off to improve blood pressure.

The patient's corneal ulcer is likely related to neurologic deficits and requires ophthalmology follow-up. Elevated liver function tests are improving but the etiology is unclear. An accelerated idioventricular rhythm

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of hypertension and ITP admitted with neurologic changes and diagnosed with Lyme encephalitis. The patient has multiple medical complications and conditions that require ongoing monitoring and management.

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation due to acute respiratory failure. The tracheostomy tube placement is at the fifth-sixth centimeter above the carina. The recent chest X-ray shows improvement, reducing the likelihood of pneumonia. The plan is to continue weaning off the ventilator as tolerated.

2. Altered Mental Status: The patient has persistent altered mental status attributed to encephalitis, although other factors like electrolyte abnormalities, concurrent infections, or medication-related causes may also contribute. Frequent reorientation and minimizing medications are part of the management plan.

3. Hypotension: The patient has had episodes of hypotension with systolic blood pressures in the 80s. IV fluids and stopping some antihypertensive medications have been initiated to address this issue.

4. Metabolic Alkalosis: The patient's bicarbonate levels are trending upward. Further evaluation with urine chloride and administration of diamox (acetazolamide) will be done to manage this condition.

5. Lyme Encephalitis: The patient is on a stable treatment course with ceftriaxone for Lyme encephalitis. This treatment will continue for another two days,

   - Pt has been on Methadone 10 mg TID for chronic pain control issues

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of hypertension, ITP, admitted for neurologic changes and diagnosed with Lyme encephalitis. He continues to have altered mental status and fever. The patient's respiratory status has improved, making pneumonia less likely. The patient is on a stable treatment course with ceftriaxone for planned 4 weeks. Persistent neurological deficits are expected, and neurology is following up. The patient's agitation may be multifactorial, including electrolyte abnormalities, concurrent infections, and medication-related factors. Seroquel has been increased and then decreased due to sedation and apnea. Tracheostomy tube trial is planned today. The patient has metabolic alkalosis with normalized bicarb, but the source is unclear. Hypotension episodes have occurred, possibly related to Seroquel. Antibiotics were started for presumed hospital-acquired pneumonia but have since been discontinued due to negative cultures. Other issues include corneal ulcer, elevated liver function tests, hypernatremia, and an accelerated idioventricular rhythm.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of hypertension, ITP, and now admitted with neurologic changes and found to have Lyme encephalitis. He has been transferred with continued altered mental status and fever. The patient is on stable treatment course for planned 4 weeks with ceftriaxone. Some persistent neurologic deficits are noted. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient has periods of apnea when sleeping, and there is a concern for respiratory failure, although it is not ARDS.
2. Metabolic alkalosis: The patient has bicarb normalized, but the cause of metabolic alkalosis is unclear.
3. Hypotension: The patient has been having periods of hypotension with SBPs in the 80s, which responded to IV fluids. There was a concern for hospital-acquired pneumonia, but recent cultures have been negative.
4. Fever: The patient had low-grade temperatures until [2102-10-16] at 4pm, but now he has a low-grade fever again. There were additional antibiotics given due to transient hypotensive episodes, but recent cultures are negative.
5. Lyme encephalitis: The patient has been diagnosed with Lyme encephalitis, and he is almost done with a 4-week course of ceftriaxone.
6. Corneal ulcer: The patient has a corneal ulcer likely related to his neurologic

The patient's vital signs are within normal limits, but he has had periods of apnea while sleeping. The patient's recent lab results show normal white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet levels, with slightly elevated creatinine and liver enzymes. The patient's electrolytes are mostly within normal limits, except for elevated sodium levels. The patient's recent imaging shows stable atelectasis and no overt pulmonary edema.

   sedation and restraints with frequent re-orientation. Will try to

   but will try to wean this off as not clear that pt is in pain and that
   he needs it. Currently tapering. Today day #2 of 3 days at 5 TID, then
   will go to 3 days at 2.5 TID
   - Currently on Seroquel 12.5 [**Hospital1 **] with hs dose 25mg; added PRN 25mg for
   agitation at night given that he was agitated last night
   - Needs EKG monitoring of QRS
   # Respiratory failure: CXR yesterday does appear improved, making PNA

   extended time period of  trach collar and does well with it.
   - Continue inhaled meds as prior for bronchospasm (no clear history of

   - Will get ABG today

   suggesting he is not volume depleted. Not related to hypokalemia as K+
   is normal. Unclear source.
   -Will discuss with renal attending tomorrow
   - Will not give more acetazolamide at this time, but continue to

   -ABG today to reassess
   # Hypotension (resolved): Has previously had periods of hypotension
   with SBPs to 80s.  Responded to IV fluids and started on vanc, cefepime
   and cipro for a presumed hospital acquired pneumonia (had had CXR that
   showed possible new RLL infiltrates).  Will try stopping some
   antihypertensives and see if this improves. D/c clonodine given that he
   is on metoprolol for control of HR after an accelerated idioventricular
   rhythm. Per nursing, patient did have some of his episodes of
   hypotension immediately after seroquel evening dose.
   - Currently tapering clonodine

   - He had had a cards consult for tachycardia, which they felt was an
   accelerated idioventricular rhythm, given metoprolol for this.
   -Timing of meds: patient is getting many of his medications together,
   may be causing hypotensive periods. Touch base with nursing to ensure
   staggered timing of meds
   # Fever.  Daily low grade temps [**Date range (1) 9233**] (100-100.3), then was

s were added on

   the idea that if he has a true infection, it would declare itself with
   elevated WBC
s and high fevers. His WBC count still remains low. All

s. No clear
   infectious source other than the IgM Lyme.
   - If febrile again, needs recultures of everything
   - Hold off on starting any ABx for now
   # Corneal ulcer.  s/p eyelid suturing with ophthal.  Likely related to
   inability to protect eye with neurologic deficits.
   - vigamox and bacitracin ointment.
   - f/u ophthalmology recs specifically duration of eye drops and f/u as

Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

1. The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of hypertension, intracranial thrombosis, and Lyme disease. He was admitted with neurologic changes and found to have Lyme encephalitis. He has been treated with ceftriaxone for four weeks but still has persistent neurologic deficits.

2. The patient's agitation and altered mental status are primarily due to encephalitis, but could also be caused by electrolyte abnormalities, other concurrent infections, or medications. The patient responds well to haloperidol (Haldol) on an as-needed basis, but efforts will be made to minimize chemical sedation and restraints.

3. The patient is currently on methadone for chronic pain control, but a gradual tapering off will be attempted as it is unclear if the patient is in pain and if he needs it.

4. The patient's respiratory failure is improving, with a recent chest X-ray showing improvement. The patient has been on extended time period tracheostomy collar and does well with it. Inhaled medications will continue to be administered for bronchospasm.

5. The patient has metabolic alkalosis, with bicarbonate levels normalized. The source of the alkalosis is unclear, but it is not related to hypokalemia as the potassium levels are normal. Monitoring will continue, and an arterial blood

Based on the provided progress note, there are several potential medical complications that can arise. These include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has impaired respiration and gas exchange, indicating a risk of respiratory failure. This is further supported by the presence of atelectasis or pneumonia on the chest X-ray.

2. Metabolic alkalosis: The patient's bicarbonate levels have normalized, but the cause of metabolic alkalosis remains unclear. It is important to monitor and reassess the ABG to confirm the diagnosis and determine the appropriate treatment.

3. Hypotension: The patient has been experiencing episodes of hypotension with SBPs in the 80s. This could be due to various factors such as sepsis, medication side effects, or fluid imbalances. Close monitoring and adjustment of fluids and medications are necessary to manage this condition.

4. Fever: Despite being on ceftriaxone, the patient continues to have low-grade temperatures. This could indicate an ongoing infection or a non-infectious cause. Further investigation, including cultures and blood tests, is needed to identify the underlying cause.

5. Corneal ulcer: The patient has a corneal ulceration that is likely related to neurologic deficits and an inability to protect the eye. Ophthalmology follow-up is recommended for proper management.

6. Elevated liver function tests (LFTs): The patient initially had elevated LFTs, but they have since normalized. The etiology of the elevated

The patient is a 70-year-old male who is currently admitted to the ICU. The patient's chief complaint is not specified in the provided note. The patient's condition has been fluctuating, with periods of improvement followed by worsening symptoms. The patient is on various medications, including heparin sodium for prophylaxis and fibresource HN for nutrition. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits, but the patient exhibits agitation and impaired cognitive function. The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, and abnormal kidney function. The patient is also experiencing respiratory failure, altered mental status, and constipation. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's impaired respiration/gas exchange and reliance on a tracheostomy tube suggest the possibility of respiratory failure. This could be due to underlying lung disease or complications from mechanical ventilation.
2. Delirium: The patient's agitation and impaired cognitive function may indicate delirium, which is common in ICU patients. Delirium can lead to increased risk of falls, worsening respiratory status, and other complications.
3. Constipation: The patient's altered elimination related to constipation is a concern. Prolonged bed rest and certain medications can contribute to constipation, which may further compromise the patient's overall condition if not managed appropriately.
4. Kidney Dysfunction: The patient's abnormal kidney function tests indicate possible kidney dysfunction. This can lead to electrolyte

Summary:
The patient's chief complaint is not mentioned in the provided information. However, based on the progress note, it can be inferred that the patient is experiencing respiratory acidosis and metabolic alkalosis as indicated by the ABG results (7.43/57/117/39). The patient has been discussed on renal rounds tomorrow and will be seen by an ophthalmologist. The patient's allergies include Ativan (Lorazepam), Ibuprofen, and Unknown. The last dose of antibiotics was Ceftriaxone on [**2102-10-23**] at 07:26 AM.

The patient is currently receiving heparin sodium for prophylaxis and haloperidol (Haldol) for sedation. Other medications include changes to the medical and family history. The patient's review of systems remains unchanged from admission except as noted below.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.2 C (99 F), heart rate of 101 bpm (range: 77-111 bpm), blood pressure of 96/61 mmHg (range: 69-151/93-106 mmHg), respiratory rate of 10 breaths per minute (range: 10-30 breaths per minute), and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient's rhythm is sinus tachycardia.

The patient's weight is 85.6 kg (admission weight: 83.1 kg) and height is 70 inches. The fluid balance shows a total intake of 2,932 mL with 460 mL given by PO, 1,752 mL given by TF, and 1,120 mL given by IVF. The total output includes 1,860 mL of urine and 385 mL of NG output. The respiratory support includes delivery through a trach mask with an SpO2 of 96% and ABG results of 7.43/57/117/35/11. The PaO2/FiO2 ratio is 234.

Physical examination findings include not assessed peripheral vascular status, skin, and neurologic examination. The labs show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, platelet count, blood urea nitrogen, creatinine, TCO2, and glucose levels. The electrolytes are within normal range except for slightly low potassium and bicarbonate levels. The other lab results include elevated liver enzymes (ALT/AST), amylase, lipase, LDH, and lactic acid levels.

The assessment and plan include impaired arousal, attention, and cognition, balance, muscle performance, respiration/gas exchange, and elimination. The patient is also diagnosed with respiratory failure, Lyme disease, altered mental status, and Bell's palsy. The patient's code status is full code, and the disposition is ICU care.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the provided information include worsening respiratory failure, further deterioration in mental status, infection due to prolonged ICU stay, and potential complications related to constipation and immobility.

   Bells Palsy
   63M with HTN, ITP, admitted with neurologic changes and found to have
   lyme encephalitis s/p 4 week treatment course with ceftriaxone.  Now
   transferred with continued altered mental status and fevers.
   # Agitation/altered mental status. Primarily due to lyme encephalitis,
   though could be multifactorial - electrolyte abnormalities, other
   concurrent infection, med related.  Also with some chronic narcotic
   use.  He responds well to PRN haldol, but we will try to avoid chemical
   sedation and restraints with frequent re-orientation. Will try to
   minimize all medications. Seroquel dose currently 12.5 [**Hospital1 **] (morning,
   afternoon), qhs 25mg; also 25 mg PRN agitation at night. Patient also
   required Haldol for agitation last night.
   - Pt has been on Methadone 10 mg TID for chronic pain control issues
   but will try to wean this off as not clear that pt is in pain and that
   he needs it. Currently tapering. Today day #3 of 3 days at 5 TID, then
   will go to 3 days at 2.5 TID
   - Currently on Seroquel 12.5 [**Hospital1 **] with hs dose 25mg; PRN 25mg for
   agitation at night
   # Respiratory failure: Patient has been on trach collar since Sunday,
   tolerating well. CXR improved, making PNA less likely. Sputum cultures
   have been negative.  He has been on extended time period of  trach
   collar and does well with it. Respiratory acidosis and metabolic
   alkalosis. Patient most likely chronic COPD.
   - Continue inhaled meds as prior for bronchospasm (no clear history of
   COPD, though with significant smoking history).
   #Metabolic Alkalosis: Bicarb normalized. Urine chloride was normal,
   suggesting he is not volume depleted. Not related to hypokalemia as K+
   is normal. Unclear source.
   -Will discuss with renal attending tomorrow
   - Will not give more acetazolamide at this time, but continue to
   monitor.
   # Hypotension (resolved): Has previously had periods of hypotension
   with SBPs to 80s.  Responded to IV fluids and started on vanc, cefepime
   and cipro for a presumed hospital acquired pneumonia (had had CXR that
   showed possible new RLL infiltrates).  Will try stopping some
   antihypertensives and see if this improves. D/c clonodine given that he
   is on metoprolol for control of HR after an accelerated idioventricular
   rhythm. Per nursing, patient did have some of his episodes of
   hypotension immediately after seroquel evening dose.
   - Currently tapering clonodine
   - Clonodine taper: 0.1mg daily x3 days, done today
   - He had had a cards consult for tachycardia, which they felt was an
   accelerated idioventricular rhythm, given metoprolol for this.
   -Timing of meds: patient is getting many of his medications together,
   may be causing hypotensive periods. Touch base with nursing to ensure
   staggered timing of meds
   # Fever.  Daily low grade temps [**Date range (1) 9233**] (100-100.3), then was
   afebrile for a while, but now having some low grade temps more recently
   ([**10-24**]). Was only on Ceftriaxone, but several more ABx
s were added on
   due to transient hypotense episodes, and then they were pulled off with
   the idea that if he has a true infection, it would declare itself with
   elevated WBC
s and high fevers. His WBC count still remains low. All
   recent cultures negative. CXR bilateral base opacification, atelectasis
   vs PNA but this has been present for several previous CXR
s. No clear
   infectious source other than the IgM Lyme.
   - If febrile again, needs recultures of everything
   - Hold off on starting any ABx for now
   # Corneal ulcer.  s/p eyelid suturing with ophthal.  Likely related to
   inability to protect eye with neurologic deficits.
   - vigamox and bacitracin ointment.
   - f/u ophthalmology recs specifically duration of eye drops and f/u as
   outpatient
   # Elevated LFTs.  Normalized.  Unclear etiology, possibly due to
   ceftriaxone.
   - Continue to trend.  If he has fevers again, would further address
   -Recheck LFTs tomorrow
   #Hypernatremia (resolved): free water 250 cc q4 hours with tube feeding
   # Accelerated idioventricular rhythm.  Cards saw; thought benign and
   not related to lyme disease.
   - Continue metoprolol at current dosing.
   FEN: correct/replete electrolytes, tube feeds
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, H2B
   Access: Peripherals, PICC was pulled out a little bit 2 days ago, but
   is still usable, just not a central line

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of hypertension, ITP, admitted with neurologic changes and diagnosed with Lyme encephalitis after a 4-week treatment course with ceftriaxone. He has been transferred with continued altered mental status and fevers.

The potential medical complications that can arise for this patient include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has been on a tracheostomy collar since Sunday and tolerating it well. He has an improved chest X-ray, making pneumonia less likely. However, he still has respiratory acidosis and metabolic alkalosis, suggesting chronic COPD.

2. Metabolic alkalosis: The patient's bicarbonate levels are normalized, and urine chloride is normal, suggesting he is not volume depleted. The cause of metabolic alkalosis is unclear, and further discussion with the renal attending is planned.

3. Hypotension: The patient has had periods of hypotension with systolic blood pressures in the 80s. This may be related to medication side effects or interactions. Adjustments to antihypertensive medications and IV fluids have been made to address this issue.

4. Fever: The patient has had daily low-grade temperatures, which may indicate an ongoing infection. Recent cultures have been negative, and the source of infection is unclear. It is important to continue monitoring his temperature and consider recultures if he develops fevers again.

5. Corneal ulcer:

   but will try to wean this off as not clear that pt is in pain and that
   he needs it. Currently tapering. Today day #3 of 3 days at 5 TID, then
   will go to 3 days at 2.5 TID
   - Currently on Seroquel 12.5 [**Hospital1 **] with hs dose 25mg; PRN 25mg for
   agitation at night
   # Respiratory failure: CXR improved, making PNA less likely. Sputum
   cultures have been negative.  He has been on extended time period of
   trach collar and does well with it. Respiratory acidosis and metabolic
   alkalosis. Patient most likely chronic COPD.
   - Continue inhaled meds as prior for bronchospasm (no clear history of
   COPD, though with significant smoking history).
   #Metabolic Alkalosis: Bicarb normalized. Urine chloride was normal,
   suggesting he is not volume depleted. Not related to hypokalemia as K+
   is normal. Unclear source.
   -Will discuss with renal attending tomorrow
   - Will not give more acetazolamide at this time, but continue to
   monitor.
   # Hypotension (resolved): Has previously had periods of hypotension
   with SBPs to 80s.  Responded to IV fluids and started on vanc, cefepime
   and cipro for a presumed hospital acquired pneumonia (had had CXR that
   showed possible new RLL infiltrates).  Will try stopping some
   antihypertensives and see if this improves. D/c clonodine given that he
   is on metoprolol for control of HR after an accelerated idioventricular
   rhythm. Per nursing, patient did have some of his episodes of
   hypotension immediately after seroquel evening dose.
   - Currently tapering clonodine
   - Clonodine taper: 0.1mg daily x3 days, done today
   - He had had a cards consult for tachycardia, which they felt was an
   accelerated idioventricular rhythm, given metoprolol for this.
   -Timing of meds: patient is getting many of his medications together,
   may be causing hypotensive periods. Touch base with nursing to ensure
   staggered timing of meds
   # Fever.  Daily low grade temps [**Date range (1) 9233**] (100-100.3), then was
   afebrile for a while, but now having some low grade temps more recently
   ([**10-24**]). Was only on Ceftriaxone, but several more ABx
s were added on
   due to transient hypotense episodes, and then they were pulled off with
   the idea that if he has a true infection, it would declare itself with
   elevated WBC
s and high fevers. His WBC count still remains low. All
   recent cultures negative. CXR bilateral base opacification, atelectasis
   vs PNA but this has been present for several previous CXR
s. No clear
   infectious source other than the IgM Lyme.
   - If febrile again, needs recultures of everything
   - Hold off on starting any ABx for now
   # Corneal ulcer.  s/p eyelid suturing with ophthal.  Likely related to
   inability to protect eye with neurologic deficits.
   - vigamox and bacitracin ointment.
   - f/u ophthalmology recs specifically duration of eye drops and f/u as
   outpatient
   # Elevated LFTs.  Normalized.  Unclear etiology, possibly due to
   ceftriaxone.
   - Continue to trend.  If he has fevers again, would further address
   -Recheck LFTs tomorrow
   #Hypernatremia (resolved): free water 250 cc q4 hours with tube feeding
   # Accelerated idioventricular rhythm.  Cards saw; thought benign and
   not related to lyme disease.
   - Continue metoprolol at current dosing.
   FEN: correct/replete electrolytes, tube feeds

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of hypertension, intracerebral thrombosis (ITP), admitted with neurologic changes and diagnosed with Lyme encephalitis after a four-week treatment course of ceftriaxone. The patient continues to have altered mental status and fevers.

The potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient has impaired respiration/gas exchange and chronic COPD. He requires inhaled medications for bronchospasm and extended time on tracheal collar. There is also respiratory acidosis and metabolic alkalosis.
2. Metabolic alkalosis: The bicarb is normalized, and urine chloride is normal, suggesting he is not volume depleted. However, the source of metabolic alkalosis is unclear.
3. Hypotension: The patient previously had periods of hypotension with systolic blood pressures in the 80s. He responded to IV fluids and started on vancomycin, cefepime, and cipro for presumed hospital-acquired pneumonia.
4. Fever: The patient has had daily low-grade temperatures, ranging from 100-100.3 degrees Fahrenheit. Recent cultures have been negative, and there is no clear infectious source other than the IgM Lyme.
5. Corneal ulcer: The patient has a corneal ulcer that is likely related to his neurologic deficits. He is being treated with vigamox and bac

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of hypertension, ITP, and admitted with neurologic changes due to Lyme encephalitis. He was previously treated with ceftriaxone for four weeks and then transferred to another facility with continued altered mental status and fevers.

The patient is currently experiencing agitation and altered mental status, which is primarily attributed to Lyme encephalitis, but could also be due to electrolyte abnormalities, concurrent infections, or medication-related issues. The patient has been prescribed Seroquel at a dose of 12.5 mg [**Hospital1**] with an additional 25 mg PRN for agitation at night. He also required Haldol for agitation last night.

The patient has respiratory failure, with previous tracheostomy and tolerance. A chest X-ray showed improvement, making pneumonia less likely. Sputum cultures have been negative, and the patient is expected to continue with inhaled medications for bronchospasm.

The patient has metabolic alkalosis, with normalized bicarbonate levels. The cause of this condition is unclear, but it is likely related to his respiratory acidosis. The patient's renal attending believes that it is mostly related to respiratory acidosis.

The patient previously had hypotension, which resolved with IV fluids and antibiotics for presumed hospital-acquired pneumonia. He was also started on metoprolol for an accelerated idioventricular rhythm, but this has been resolved after

   [**Hospital1 **] (morning, afternoon), qhs 25mg; also 25 mg PRN agitation at night.

   - Pt has been on Methadone 10 mg TID for chronic pain control issues,

   - Currently on Seroquel 12.5 [**Hospital1 **] with hs dose 25mg; PRN 25mg for
   agitation at night
   # Respiratory failure: Patient has been on trach collar since Sunday,
   tolerating well. CXR improved, making PNA less likely. Sputum cultures
   have been negative.  He has been on extended time period of  trach
   collar and does well with it. Respiratory acidosis and metabolic
   alkalosis. Patient most likely chronic COPD.
   - Continue inhaled meds as prior for bronchospasm (no clear history of
   COPD, though with significant smoking history).

s were added on due to transient

s. No clear infectious source

He has been transferred to the ICU with continued altered mental status and fevers.

The patient's current medical conditions and potential complications include:

1. Arousal, attention, and cognition impaired: The patient exhibits impaired arousal, attention, and cognition due to Lyme encephalitis.
2. Balance impaired: The patient's balance is impaired, which could increase the risk of falls and injuries.
3. Knowledge impaired: The patient's knowledge is impaired, indicating difficulty in understanding or remembering information.
4. Muscle performance impaired: The patient's muscle performance is impaired, which may affect his ability to move and perform activities of daily living.
5. Respiration/gas exchange impaired: The patient has respiratory failure, specifically acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
6. Transfers impaired: The patient's ability to transfer from one place to another is impaired, requiring assistance.
7. Elimination alteration related to constipation: The patient has altered elimination function due to constipation.
8. Bell's Palsy: The patient has been diagnosed with Bell's Palsy, a condition characterized by facial muscle weakness or paralysis.
9. Agitation/altered mental status: The patient experiences agitation

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of hypertension, ITP, admitted with neurologic changes and diagnosed with Lyme encephalitis after a four-week treatment course of ceftriaxone. He was transferred to the ICU with continued altered mental status and fevers. The patient's current concerns include agitation/altered mental status, respiratory failure, bloody bowel movement, and metabolic alkalosis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Agitation/Altered Mental Status: The patient has been experiencing agitation and altered mental status, primarily due to Lyme encephalitis. However, it could also be multifactorial, including electrolyte abnormalities, concurrent infections, and medication-related effects. The patient is currently on Seroquel for agitation, and the dose is being adjusted.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient has been on a tracheostomy collar since Sunday and tolerating it well. His recent CXR showed improvement, making pneumonia less likely. Sputum cultures have been negative. The patient most likely has chronic COPD, and inhaled medications are being continued for bronchospasm.

3. Bloody Bowel Movement: The patient had a large bloody bowel movement, which raised concern for gastrointestinal bleeding. Further assessment is needed, including a kidney/ureter/bladder (KUB) ultrasound to rule out free air, abdominal pain, and ongoing blood loss.

Summary:
The patient is a 70-year-old male admitted to the ICU with altered mental status and respiratory failure. The patient has a history of Bell's palsy, Lyme disease, and is on methadone for pain management. 

The patient's condition has been fluctuating, with an increase in HCT from 10-25% to 34.4% at 3 am on 10/26, indicating possible hemoconcentration due to dehydration. The patient's sodium level is high at 145 mEq/L, suggesting hypernatremia. 

The patient's blood pressure is within normal range, but there is a significant drop in systolic blood pressure from 113 mmHg to 92 mmHg over the last 24 hours. The patient's heart rate is stable, but there is a slight increase in respiratory rate.

The patient's oxygen saturation is consistently above 95%, indicating adequate oxygenation. 

The patient has a history of constipation, as evidenced by the large bloody bowel movement at 2130. The patient's white blood cell count is slightly elevated, but other lab values including hemoglobin, platelet count, creatinine, and electrolytes are within normal limits. 

The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) results show normal oxygen and carbon dioxide levels, pH within normal range, and slightly elevated bicarbonate level. 

The patient's physical examination reveals no abnormalities in peripheral vascular, skin, or neurologic assessments.

The patient also has a pain complaint in the right upper quadrant (RUQ), which could be due to biliary colic, ulcer disease, or acalculous cholecystitis, especially considering prolonged use of ceftriaxone. Further evaluation with LFTs, lipase, RUQ ultrasound, EKG, serial troponins, and IV PPI is recommended. The patient also experienced bloody bowel movements, which could be related to hemorrhoids or an upper gastrointestinal bleed. A PEG tube lavage has been performed to assess for upper gastrointestinal bleeding, and the patient is on NPO status with active tissue and surgical consults. The patient's agitation and altered mental status may be attributed to Lyme encephalitis, electrolyte abnormalities, concurrent infections, or chronic narcotic use. Methadone is being tapered, and Seroquel has been increased. The patient has a history of chronic pain and has been on methadone 10 mg TID, currently on day 1 of 3 days at 2.5 TID. The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with significant smoking history, and inhaled medications will be continued. Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, there are several potential medical complications that can arise for the patient:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has been on a tracheostomy collar since Sunday and is tolerating it well. However, they still have impaired respiration/gas exchange due to chronic COPD.

2. Metabolic alkalosis: The patient has an alteration in elimination related to constipation, which may contribute to metabolic alkalosis. Further investigation is needed to determine the underlying cause.

3. Hypernatremia: The patient has a high sodium level that needs to be carefully managed with free water administration and rechecking of sodium levels.

4. Hypotension: The patient has previously experienced periods of low blood pressure, which responded to IV fluids and antibiotic treatment for a presumed hospital-acquired pneumonia.

5. Lyme encephalitis: The patient has a history of neurologic changes and was treated with ceftriaxone for Lyme disease. However, they continue to have altered mental status and fevers, indicating ongoing neurological involvement.

6. Corneal ulcer: The patient has a corneal ulcer that required eyelid suturing and ophthalmology follow-up. This may be related to the inability to protect the eye due to neurologic deficits.

7. Accelerated idioventricular rhythm: The patient had an accelerated idioventricular rhythm, which was managed with metoprolol.

These are some of the potential medical complications that can arise based

Summary:
The patient is a 70-year-old male with a chief complaint of altered mental status. The patient has a history of multiple medical conditions including diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and Lyme disease. The patient presented to the emergency department with complaints of confusion, disorientation, and difficulty ambulating. Upon arrival, the patient was found to have a fever, hypotension, and tachycardia. Initial laboratory tests revealed elevated white blood cell count, elevated blood glucose levels, and evidence of renal dysfunction. The patient was promptly admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for close monitoring and management of his critical condition.

In the ICU, the patient has been receiving intravenous fluids, antibiotics, and supportive care. His vital signs have been stabilized, and he has shown improvement in his renal function. However, the patient continues to experience altered mental status, which has been attributed to a combination of factors including sepsis, hypoglycemia, and electrolyte imbalances.

The patient's recent progress note indicates that he experienced transient right upper quadrant (RUQ) abdominal pain, which resolved by the time of rounds. The pain prompted the cessation of tube feeds and initiation of nothing by mouth (NPO) status. Lactate levels were measured and found to be within normal range. Liver function tests (LFTs) were also obtained and revealed no abnormalities.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of hypertension, ITP, admitted with neurologic changes and diagnosed with Lyme encephalitis after a 4-week treatment course with ceftriaxone. He is now transferred with continued altered mental status and fevers.

The patient has multiple medical complications, including:

1. Pain in the RUQ: The patient experienced pain in the right upper quadrant (RUQ) that resolved after receiving IV morphine. Possible etiologies of pain in the RUQ include biliary colic, ulcer disease, and acalculous cholecystitis in the setting of ceftriaxone use for 28 days. Further evaluation is needed, including LFTs, lipase, RUQ ultrasound, EKG, serial troponins x 3, IV PPI, and GI consult.

2. Bloody bowel movement: The patient has had bloody bowel movements with some abdominal pain. The cause of the bleeding is unclear, and it could be related to hemorrhoids or an ulcer. A PEG tube lavage has been done to assess for UGI bleed, and a GI consult has been requested for possible EGD.

3. Agitation and altered mental status: The patient is experiencing agitation and altered mental status primarily due to Lyme encephalitis. Other possible causes include electrolyte abnormalities, concurrent infection, and medication-related effects. Seroquel has been started at

Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old man with a chief complaint of Lyme encephalitis. He has been in the ICU for multiple complications, including acute abdominal pain, fever, respiratory failure, AIVR (atrial arrhythmias), Lyme encephalitis, metabolic alkalosis, and a corneal ulcer.

The patient's abdominal pain has resolved, with reassuring imaging and serial exams. However, he continues to experience ongoing encephalopathy and delirium, which is being treated with medications such as methadone, clonidine, and seroquel.

The patient's respiratory failure has resolved, and he is now doing well on TC (likely tracheal cuff) for several days. He will continue to receive bronchodilators, suctioning, and use of a nasal cannula when on positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP).

The patient's fever has also resolved, and he no longer requires antibiotics.

The patient's Lyme encephalitis is now being treated off ceftriaxone, as per neurology, and there is no need for repeat lumbar puncture (LP).

The patient has metabolic alkalosis, which did not respond to a saline challenge. The etiology is unclear, but there is no present need to attempt to correct it.

The patient has a corneal ulcer, which is being treated per ophthalmology notes.

In terms of ICU care, the patient's nutrition consists of receiving Fibers
